answers.text:
Hi Rosalee, 
Unfortunately we do not have any documents on the Knowledge Network at time about creating a policy that would require the city manager to sit in on all meetings between the staff and council members. However, there is a previously asked question that deals with how to keep everyone informed and up to date on all the issues that may be something to think about while crafting your policy.http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/questions/question/22658
I hope other local government officials are able to provide you with specific answers and examples. 
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern
rsaywitz@icma.org

answers.author: Leslie Beauregard
answers.text:
Generally speaking if a Council member requests a meeting with a department head, that department head should inform the City Manager just as FYI.  Same with staff who should inform the department head and then the City Manager.  That practice has worked well here and other places I have worked.  The City Manager would be pressed to sit in many more meetings than already required to!

answers.author: Woody Fincham
answers.text:
Leslie mirrors my own thoughts on this topic, as it keeps the appointed CM in the loop of what is going on.  In my last position,  my department head was also an appointee and would always keep the CM abreast of any meetings with the mayor or council, but there was never a requirement that the CM be present.  Transparency and inclusion fosters trust in the long run, and prevents unwanted drama.

answers.author: Tim Ogden
answers.text:
I would wonder why is the Councilmember meeting with staff or dept heads, and whether their intent is educational or to feel inclined to direct staff to do something, which in my Council-Manager city shouldn't occur.  I prefer being the conduit with the Council when their inquiries can't be done in the public meeting which is usually best so they all get the same info and act as a body not individually.  On occasion when they have had an appropriate educational meeting with dept heads, I am just kept abreast of the meeting and that works fine when I can't attend.

answers.author: Jerry Giaimis
answers.text:
All members of my governing body know that according to NJ code regarding the CM form of government, all administrative service goes through the manager.  If they need to speak to a department head to get a clearer understanding on an issue they must request to do so from me.  Prior to determining whether or not I "sit in" on the meeting I need to have a clear understanding on what information they are requesting.   If I do not sit in, I ask the staff member to give a brief update on the conversation after it occurs.

answers.author: Michael Maniscalco
answers.text:
This is one of my largest challenges. I have some Councilors who like to go on expeditions in an effort to find information that makes others look bad and put the staff in the middle. I have recommended policies and even brought an attorney in to explain how Manager-Council gov works. At the end of the day I have had to rely on the staff to report  to me what information was being sought and then distribute it to the entire Council.

text: Trying to determine if anyone has in place or is in the process of creating a policy whereby the City Manager / Deputy City Manager is required to sit in on all meetings (requested by either staff or Council) between staff members and Council members...
title: City Manager in all meetings between staff and Council
